prompt: A courier says they need urgent access to deliver equipment for IT.
option_a: Let them in and show them to the IT area.
option_b: Ask who they're delivering to and confirm with IT via reception.
option_c: Ignore them and continue working.
rationale_correct: Always verify with the intended recipient or reception before granting access.
rationale_wrong: Tailgating and impersonation are common physical social engineering tactics.

prompt: You receive an email marked 'Urgent Payroll Correction' asking you to confirm your bank details.
option_a: Click the link and update details immediately.
option_b: Forward the email to IT and wait for guidance.
option_c: Reply asking if the email is real.
rationale_correct: Forward suspicious emails using the official phishing report method.
rationale_wrong: Never click or reply directly to unknown or suspicious senders.

prompt: A colleague on Teams asks for your login to access a shared folder while IT is offline.
option_a: Share your login to help them meet the deadline.
option_b: Suggest they log a ticket with IT instead.
option_c: Ignore them completely.
rationale_correct: Never share passwords. Always use official access or ticket systems.
rationale_wrong: Account sharing breaches policy and opens vulnerabilities.

prompt: While travelling, you need to send client files but only have access to café Wi-Fi.
option_a: Send the files using the café Wi-Fi — it's password protected.
option_b: Use your mobile hotspot or VPN connection to send them.
option_c: Wait until you're back in the office to send them.
rationale_correct: Use secure connections like VPNs or mobile hotspots for sensitive work.
rationale_wrong: Public Wi-Fi can be intercepted even if it has a password.

prompt: You see an AI plugin that claims to automate meeting notes.
option_a: Install it to save time.
option_b: Ask IT if the tool is approved before installing.
option_c: Ignore it; you don’t need notes.
rationale_correct: Only approved AI tools should process business or client data.
rationale_wrong: Unverified AI tools can leak sensitive information.

prompt: A supplier sends an invoice from a slightly different domain than usual.
option_a: Pay it to avoid late fees.
option_b: Call your finance contact using known details to confirm.
option_c: Reply to the sender for clarification.
rationale_correct: Always verify changes using official contact info, not reply-to addresses.
rationale_wrong: Domain spoofing is a classic business email compromise tactic.

prompt: An unknown number calls saying they’re from 'Corporate IT' and need to reset your password.
option_a: Provide your username to help them verify.
option_b: Hang up and contact IT using official channels.
option_c: Ask them to email you for proof.
rationale_correct: Legitimate IT staff will never call asking for credentials.
rationale_wrong: Always re-initiate suspicious contact yourself via official numbers.

prompt: A teammate leaves their unlocked laptop on their desk during lunch.
option_a: Lock their screen for them.
option_b: Take a photo and message them to lock it next time.
option_c: Ignore it — not your responsibility.
rationale_correct: Locking the workstation helps protect sensitive data.
rationale_wrong: We’re all responsible for maintaining security awareness.

prompt: You accidentally send a file with personal data to the wrong client.
option_a: Recall the email and delete it from Sent.
option_b: Report it immediately to your manager or DPO.
option_c: Wait and hope they delete it.
rationale_correct: Prompt reporting enables fast containment and compliance action.
rationale_wrong: Delays increase the risk of breach escalation.

prompt: Your team Slack channel includes an external freelancer. You need to share a client password.
option_a: Send it privately over Slack DMs.
option_b: Use the approved password manager or secure note feature.
option_c: Email it from your work address.
rationale_correct: Passwords should only be shared using secure vault tools.
rationale_wrong: Chat and email aren’t encrypted end-to-end.

prompt: Someone messages you on LinkedIn asking for insights about a project under NDA.
option_a: Share general details — it’s good networking.
option_b: Politely decline and report the message.
option_c: Forward them internal slides without client names.
rationale_correct: NDA projects must not be discussed outside authorised channels.
rationale_wrong: Even vague details can expose confidential work.

prompt: Your manager asks you to approve an expense via email while travelling.
option_a: Check sender details and approve through the finance system.
option_b: Approve via reply to save time.
option_c: Ignore it until you're back at your desk.
rationale_correct: Always use verified systems for approvals; check sender authenticity.
rationale_wrong: Email approvals can be spoofed or misused.

prompt: You receive a Zoom invite from a supplier you’ve never worked with before.
option_a: Join the meeting to see what it’s about.
option_b: Check with your project manager before joining.
option_c: Delete the invite without checking.
rationale_correct: Always confirm legitimacy before engaging with unknown contacts.
rationale_wrong: Unverified invites can contain phishing links or meeting hijacks.

prompt: A pop-up says your system will shut down unless you update antivirus manually.
option_a: Click and follow the link to update.
option_b: Run a check through your official IT software center.
option_c: Ignore it; probably nothing.
rationale_correct: Only update software via official IT tools or company app stores.
rationale_wrong: Pop-ups are a common malware distribution vector.

prompt: You want to share design files with a client who struggles to access SharePoint.
option_a: Send them a Dropbox link instead.
option_b: Ask IT to enable a secure guest access option.
option_c: Send it to their personal Gmail.
rationale_correct: Always use authorised systems with controlled access.
rationale_wrong: External file sharing must remain compliant and auditable.

prompt: You notice a colleague downloading software from an unverified website.
option_a: Tell them to stop and report to IT.
option_b: Let them finish — they probably know what they’re doing.
option_c: Download it too; it might be useful.
rationale_correct: Unapproved downloads can introduce malware.
rationale_wrong: Security is everyone’s responsibility — act when you spot risky behaviour.

prompt: You’re asked to share an internal survey publicly on social media.
option_a: Check if it contains internal or client info before sharing.
option_b: Post it immediately — it’s harmless PR.
option_c: Share via your personal LinkedIn.
rationale_correct: Always review for confidential or internal details before public posting.
rationale_wrong: Even internal surveys can contain business-sensitive data.

prompt: Your browser warns you a site’s certificate has expired.
option_a: Proceed anyway; it’s probably fine.
option_b: Stop and alert IT about the issue.
option_c: Try another browser to bypass it.
rationale_correct: Certificate warnings can signal phishing or outdated encryption.
rationale_wrong: Proceeding could expose credentials or client data.

prompt: A file download completes with the name 'Invoice.zip.exe'.
option_a: Run it to check if it’s genuine.
option_b: Delete it and inform IT immediately.
option_c: Rename the file and open it carefully.
rationale_correct: Files with double extensions often hide malware.
rationale_wrong: Never run unverified executable files.

prompt: You overhear colleagues discussing client data in a café.
option_a: Join in quietly to contribute.
option_b: Remind them politely to avoid discussing confidential data in public.
option_c: Ignore it — you’re not part of that project.
rationale_correct: Protecting data in public spaces is part of confidentiality best practice.
rationale_wrong: Even overheard conversations can risk client privacy.

prompt: Your email signature still includes an old client logo from two years ago.
option_a: Update it using the latest approved branding pack.
option_b: Leave it — it still looks fine.
option_c: Remove the logo entirely to simplify.
rationale_correct: Outdated branding can cause confusion or reputational issues.
rationale_wrong: Always follow official templates for external communication.

prompt: Someone posts a QR code flyer on the office noticeboard.
option_a: Scan it to see what it links to.
option_b: Ask facilities or security to review and approve it first.
option_c: Ignore it — probably a team event.
rationale_correct: Unverified QR codes can link to malicious or phishing sites.
rationale_wrong: Treat physical QR codes like any other unknown link.

prompt: You’re working remotely from a shared co-working space.
option_a: Use a privacy screen and lock screen when stepping away.
option_b: Leave your laptop on standby while you grab coffee.
option_c: Connect to the shared Wi-Fi without VPN for speed.
rationale_correct: Physical and network hygiene matters when working remotely.
rationale_wrong: Public or semi-public spaces need additional security measures.

prompt: A journalist asks for comment about a client project.
option_a: Direct them to the company’s communications team.
option_b: Give a neutral answer off the record.
option_c: Share what’s already public on LinkedIn.
rationale_correct: External media requests must go through official channels.
rationale_wrong: Off-record comments can still breach confidentiality.

prompt: You get a direct message from 'CEO' asking you to buy gift cards for clients urgently.
option_a: Buy them immediately to be helpful.
option_b: Verify through another channel before acting.
option_c: Ignore it completely.
rationale_correct: Always verify unexpected urgent requests, especially financial ones.
rationale_wrong: Classic impersonation scam — verify before acting.

prompt: You notice sensitive data printed and left in a meeting room.
option_a: Collect it and deliver to the owner or shred it.
option_b: Leave it; someone will pick it up.
option_c: Take a photo to remind them later.
rationale_correct: Never leave or photograph sensitive printed materials — secure or destroy them.
rationale_wrong: Physical data leaks are just as risky as digital ones.

prompt: You’re filling in a survey about cybersecurity habits.
option_a: Answer honestly — it’s anonymous.
option_b: Share it externally for others to benchmark.
option_c: Ignore it; you don’t have time.
rationale_correct: Internal surveys help identify training needs; keep responses internal.
rationale_wrong: Surveys may include company-specific data — don’t share externally.

prompt: A client asks you to send them data that includes personal information.
option_a: Send it encrypted or via secure portal after confirming purpose.
option_b: Send it via email to save time.
option_c: Refuse to send any data at all.
rationale_correct: Data sharing must be controlled, with appropriate encryption and purpose validation.
rationale_wrong: Balance compliance and business need — safe sharing, not refusal.

prompt: A team member messages you their MFA code saying 'it’s for testing'.
option_a: Use it to help them troubleshoot.
option_b: Report it and remind them never to share codes.
option_c: Ignore the message.
rationale_correct: MFA codes are private — report if someone shares one.
rationale_wrong: Sharing MFA codes undermines security for everyone.

prompt: You find a lost USB stick in the car park.
option_a: Plug it in to identify the owner.
option_b: Hand it to security or IT without connecting it.
option_c: Throw it away.
rationale_correct: Unknown media should never be plugged in; hand to IT for inspection.
rationale_wrong: USBs can contain malware that activates on connection.
